timeline.text:
This is a prototypical world in a 1950s sci-fi film. 


It takes place in a world similar to one in which the viewer lives. But…
… there's an existential threat looming in the background. It's mysterious, scary – and a bit exciting.
In the story, the protagonists explore this phenomenon.
They use science and technology to learn more about it.
And eventually, they figure it out. It's the triumph of humanity.

I analyzed the top 200¹ sci-fi films and tv shows from the 1950s to present day. What I found was that sci-fi stories from yesteryear were quite different from today's stories.
¹ These are the films and tv shows IMDB categorizes as science fiction. The top 200 are based on the number of votes the film or tv show received from IMDB users.
In the 1950s, most sci-fi films and shows took place in the audience's present day – so, the 1950s.
In these 1950s stories, the world is often upended by an existential threat.

timeline.hed: World is left in a better place
timeline.text: But the protagonists figure it out – and leave the world better than the beginning of the story.

Sci-fi is an amazing genre.


It helps us explore our feelings about the unknown, the future, and the possible.  It lets us imagine "what if" scenarios, and then build out rich worlds that our minds can occupy. It depicts dystopias we should fend off and utopias we should seek – and it teases us with the scintillating possibility that humans may actually be able to build the world we want.


But over the last few generations, it's been harder for us to imagine this better world – and our sci-fi reflects that.
This is a prototypical sci-fi setting in more recent years. We're in the near future – often a world that looks like ours, but with hints that something has already gone terribly wrong.
Today's sci-fi is more likely to depict a world that is worse than our reality. It's maybe even a dystopian or post-apocalyptic world
This world is almost always marked by economic inequality, human suffering, and sometimes even a militarized, authoritarian society.
In this world, the protagonists face an existential threat. And to defeat the threat, we must face societal conflicts, interpersonal conflicts, and conflicts within ourselves.
Ultimately, the story is likely to be a commentary on today's social issues. It's a warning of what is to come – or a reflection of a current reality that we've tried hard to ignore.
The changes to sci-fi stories didn't happen overnight. Sci-fi slowly evolved over the last few generations.
There's been an uptick in sci-fi stories that take place in the near future.
We're now more likely to be thrown into a dystopian or post-apocalyptic world – often a warning for what we might face.

timeline.hed: Setting is marked by economic inequality
timeline.text: This dystopian society is more likely to be marked by economic inequality.

timeline.hed: Setting is marked by human suffering
timeline.text: This often leads to more human suffering.

timeline.hed: Setting is marked by a militarized society
timeline.text: And increasingly, sci-fi stories depict militarized societies.
What hasn't changed is that sci-fi stories often have existential threats.
But in the past, those existential threats were mysterious and unknown. These were often threats to be explored, and not simply defeated.
These days, it's much more likely that protagonists have to overcome societal forces – political movements, systemic inequality, rampant capitalism.
It's also more likely for protagonists to have to overcome conflicts with another person – an authoritarian politician, a manipulative mentor, or even an ally with a different world view.
And it's now far more likely that the story explores inner conflicts – moral dilemmas, identity crises, and wrestling with our understanding of what it means to be human.

timeline.hed: Story can be seen as a commentary of current social issues
timeline.text: Ultimately, today's sci-fi stories are far more likely to be a commentary of current social issues. These might be critiques of political ideologies, runaway capitalism, irresponsible innovation, and human apathy.

The end of these films almost always ends with humans figuring it out. 


But as we walk out of the theater, we're thrust back into reality – a world where we're facing existential threats like climate change, authoritarianism, devious technology, and war. And if these sci-fi stories are prescient, it means we don't figure it out; instead, the world turns into a dystopian shitscape and only then do we figure it out.


>> Pessimistic story arc


That story arc is driven by our need for a compelling narrative. Jurassic Park author Michael Crichton once said: "Futuristic science fiction tends to be pessimistic. If you imagine a future that’s wonderful, you don’t have a story." 


>> Story arc


Perhaps because of that, critics have pointed out that our sci-fi is getting more pessimistic. Or perhaps we have actually become pessimistic; after all, news stories remind us that authoritarianism is on the rise and that earth is inevitably going to warm so much that it'll kill millions of people. Given this, how could we possibly imagine a less bleak future?


>> We are here


But maybe that's what sci-fi can explore.


Author Neal Stephenson wrote in 2011: "Good SF supplies a plausible, fully thought-out picture of an alternate reality in which some sort of compelling innovation has taken place." Pundit Noah Smith wrote that optimistic sci-fi "needs to present a future with several concrete features corresponding to the type of future people want to imagine actually living in."


So, what if we figure it out?

What if we create spaceships that explore our galaxy further than we could've ever imagined?


What if we become deeply invested in seeing – and understanding – more of the universe?

What if we built cities that support healthier, happier living? 


What if we didn't try to conquer nature, but rather live within it?

What if we ensured that even the least privileged among us have reliable housing, food, and healthcare?


What if we built a world run by people who believe it's unconscionable to kill someone else over a disagreement under the guise of "war"?
What if we built new technologies with the goal of improving our lives, rather than profiting off us?

I know, I know.


Right now, it's hard to see that future. We see terrible things all around us – hunger, disease, mass murder, greed, an uninhabitable planet.

But maybe that's why it's so important for us to imagine a different future – precisely because it is hard to see.


Because if we can't see it, how can we possibly navigate toward it?

text: The spirit of these stories is perfectly captured in this quote from Captain Nemo in< span>20,000 Leagues Under the Sea (1954). In the story, society "There is hope for the future. And when the world is ready for a new and better life, all this will someday come to pass."
